ai.summary: The Dukeries Trail is a challenging long-distance hike in the United Kingdom, covering about 129.7 km. Designed for experienced trekkers, the route presents a mix of upland moor, woodland trails, exposed open sections, and rural lanes, with significant cumulative elevation.
ai.terrain_summary: Expect a varied mix of grassy paths over rolling hills, peat bogs in upland zones, woodland tracks, country lanes, and occasional road crossings. Some sections are exposed in open moorland; path marking can be intermittent in remote stretches. Navigation and map-reading are essential.
ai.safety_notes: This is a long, strenuous journey that may require multiple days or a very demanding single push. Plan thoroughly: know your daily distances and camping options, check weather forecasts, and carry appropriate clothing for sudden changes. Always carry a reliable map and compass (GPS as backup), and inform someone of your itinerary. Water sources can be scarce in some sections, so bring sufficient water and a means to treat it. Wear sturdy, waterproof boots and use trekking poles if helpful. Be prepared for boggy ground, steep ascents, gates/stiles, and variable UK weather; carry a first aid kit, emergency blanket, whistle, and a means of communication. Leave no trace and respect livestock and wildlife.
recommended_gear: Weather-appropriate layers and a waterproof jacket
Map and compass (and GPS as backup)
Water bottle or hydration bladder (2–3 litres total capacity)
High-energy snacks and lightweight meals (for multi-day trips)
First aid kit and emergency blanket
Whistle and personal locator beacon or charged mobile for emergencies
Dry bags or waterproof stuff sacks
Emergency bivy or lightweight tarp for shelter
Extra socks and a warm hat/gloves for cold conditions
ai.best_seasons: Spring to autumn (roughly April–October) offer the best overall conditions and daylight for a 129.7 km hike. Winter can be challenging due to shorter days, colder temperatures, and often more difficult terrain; plan accordingly.
